headline: Maybe there won't be subpoenas for GOP lawmakers from Jan. 6 probe but that doesn't spell doom
sentences:
Scott Perry Letter by Daily Kos
x
x
 December 20, 2021 Representative Scott Perry United States House of Representatives 2160 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Dear Representative Perry, On June 30, 2021, the House adopted House Resolution 503, establishing the Select Committee
 to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol (the “Select Committee”).

The decision to drop the pursuit of the Republican legislators' records and testimony has “not been formalized” and ABC said their “sources caution that the committee's plans could change,” but “the emerging consensus is to proceed without taking this step.”
A representative for the Jan. 6 committee did not immediately respond to a request for comment to Daily Kos on Wednesday.

Related: Who’s who: A rolling guide to the targets of the Jan. 6 committee
According to ABC, GOP House Leader Kevin McCarthy and Reps. Jim Jordan of Ohio and Scott Perry of Pennsylvania have had “no follow-up discussions” about their cooperation since receiving their respective subpoenas.

We also ask that you provide us with all relevant electronic or other communications on these and other topics related to January 6th, including your communications with the Trump legal team, the former President himself, and others who were involved in planning the events of January 6th.

Related: Texts show Fox hosts and Trump Jr. begging Mark Meadows to get Trump to stop the insurgency
x
—@Liz_Cheney reads texts sent by Sean Hannity, Laura Ingraham, Brian Kilmeade, and Donald Trump Jr. to Mark Meadows during the insurrection, imploring him to get Trump to do something.

We are also
 aware that you had multiple text and other communications with President Trump’s former Chief
 of Staff regarding Mr. Clark
 —
 and we also have evidence indicating that in that time frame you sent communications to the former Chief of Staff using the encrypted Signal app.

Representative Scott Perry Page 2 In addition, we have information indicating that you communicated at various relevant times with the White House and others involved in other relevant topics, including regarding allegations that the Dominion voting machines had been corrupted.

That committee has no subpoena power, but it has been running a parallel investigation to the official probe for months, largely relying on U.S. Capitol Police testimony to support its contention that security and intelligence failures were solely to blame for the rioting.

In the weeks before January 6th, then-
 President Trump’s appointees
 at the Justice Department informed the President repeatedly that his claims of election fraud were not supported by the evidence, and that the election was not, in fact, stolen.

Anonymous sources cited in a report published by ABC Wednesday have cast new doubt that the Jan. 6 committee will pursue enforcement of subpoenas it has issued to a handful of sitting Republican lawmakers with alleged ties to the Capitol attack.

Reports of a similar nature have circulated for months as investigators have continued taking deposition and records from over 500 witnesses, including high- and low-level aides and Trump White House staff, election officials, and many others.

But with or without his testimony, Trump’s former White House chief of staff, Mark Meadows, has already given the probe text messages illuminating how Jordan was campaigning for then-Vice President Mike Pence to stop the certification.

Jordan has made it clear since Trump’s first impeachment when he defended the former president unflaggingly that he would relish a chance to drag Biden White House officials through public hearings should the GOP retake Congress.

Rep. Jim Jordan, for example, is among Trump’s most fierce lapdogs in Congress and has been spurned by the Jan. 6 committee already when Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi rejected his nomination to the panel by McCarthy.

Among other topics, we are examining issues relating to an effort by former President Trump and others to install Mr. Jeffrey Clark in the days before January 6, 2021, as acting Attorney General of the United States.

Acting Attorney General Rosen and acting Deputy Attorney General Donoghue have provided evidence regarding these issues, and we have received evidence that others who worked with Mr. Clark were aware of these plans.

Politico reported on March 2 that committee investigators “have repeatedly asked witnesses to describe contacts with Perry.”
The panel has already conducted over 550 interviews.

Committee members have been outwardly devoted to pursuing the investigation regardless of the political toll it exacts—Liz Cheney was ousted from her leadership role in the GOP after joining the committee.

Committee Chair Bennie Thompson has said since late last year that if those lawmakers targeted do not come forward, he was uncertain what tools the probe might have in its chest to force their testimony.

Then-President Trump considered appointing Jeffrey Clark as acting Attorney General, as Mr. Clark pressed his Department of Justice superiors to use agency authorities to challenge the election results.
Before eventually turning his back on the committee following extensive cooperation, Meadows turned over heaps of text messages and other correspondence, only some of which has been made public.
Frustrating it may be for watchers of the probe, the lack of participation by certain lawmakers does not preclude the reams of evidence and other materials the committee has already amassed.
It has taken pains to reiterate this as Republicans like Meadows, Jordan, and several others already subpoenaed actively claim the probe acts beyond the scope of its authority.
When Mr. Clark decided to invoke his 5th Amendment rights, he understood that we planned to pose questions addressing his interactions with you, among a host of other topics.
Thompson alleges that Perry was the engine behind a scheme to install a Trump-friendly lawyer Jeffrey Clark at the Department of Justice as the nation’s attorney general.
Mr. Clark has informed us that he plans to invoke his 5th Amendment right against self-incrimination in anticipation of a deposition to be conducted by the Committee.
If it would be preferable to hold this meeting with you in your district, we would also be glad to explore travel arrangements to facilitate that option.
It needs only to amass information and investigate all of the different avenues in which the attempted overthrow of the 2020 election was undertaken.
We have received evidence from multiple witnesses that you had an important role in the efforts to install Mr. Clark as acting Attorney General.
We write on behalf of the Select Committee to seek information in your possession that will advance our investigation of this and other topics.

The committee itself does not have the ability to indict anyone.
But the fact remains that political retribution could be swift if Republicans take back the House and Senate in the coming elections.

The Select Committee is investigating the facts, circumstances, and cau
 ses of the January 6th attack and issues relating thereto.

Constitutionally, Pence did not have that authority.

Investigators allege Jordan spoke to Trump on Jan. 6.
Advertising dollars have been gobbled up by Big Tech and cash-strapped outlets are being bought and sold to the highest bidder.

Sincerely, Bennie G. Thompson Chairman
Millions of books, audiobooks, magazines, documents, sheet music, and more for free.
We are primarily accountable to readers like you because donations from readers like you are our biggest source of income.
The Meadows messages alone painted a frantic picture of the White House and Washington both before and after the attack.
Jordan is a member of the powerful House Judiciary Committee and is also a member of a Jan. 6 shadow committee.
It is up to the Justice Department to decide whether it will bring a criminal indictment for his obstruction.
The Select Committee has tremendous respect for the prerogatives of Congress and the privacy of its Members.
At the same time, we have a solemn responsibility to investigate fully all of these facts and circumstances.
We would like to meet with you soon to discuss these topics, but we also want to accommodate your schedule.
If it finds criminality or evidence of criminality, it will be up to the Department of Justice to act next.
At this time, the Select Committee seeks your voluntary cooperation in addressing each of these issues.
If you are unavailable during that time period, we can arrange a time during the week of January 10th.
They have based this on Trump White House call logs received from the National Archives in February.
Jordan has flip-flopped on his account of the day, regularly buckling under scrutiny in interviews.
Forcing compliance with sitting lawmakers is tricky for the panel both politically and legally.
We propose meeting with you on December 28th, December 29th, January 3rd, or January 4th.
They argue the select committee moves as a law enforcement arm, not a legislative arm.
That's not just journalists, but fact-checkers, editors, and administrative staff.
But the committee has underlined, time and again, it does not need to indict.
We aim to make informed recommendations taking account of all relevant facts.
Please let us know whether one of those dates will fit with your schedule.
As for Perry, the committee asked him to voluntarily comply in December.
We don't have corporate backers that are only in it for the bottom line.

It's important:
 Media outlets shed 28,637 jobs last year alone.
Thank you in advance for your consideration of this request.
Meadows has since been held in contempt of Congress.
